data.title: The Roundup: No Way Out (2023)
data.meta_description: Detective Ma Seok-do changes his affiliation from the Geumcheon Police Station to the Metropolitan Investigation Team, in order to eradicate Japanese gangsters who enter Korea to commit heinous crimes.
data.text:
The Roundup was a smart refinement of The Outlaws’ cops-vs-gangsters crime thriller into an action-cop punch-em-up tailored to its lead’s unique strengths. And it was an evolution that struck box-office gold, to the tune of “Korea’s top grosser of 2022 and a top-ten spot among the country’s highest grossing films”. The Roundup: No Way Out arrives a year later as a blockbuster victory lap of sorts, doubling down on comedy, action, and villains to luxuriate in what is now a franchise formula of blistering haymakers pounding fools and goons into next week.

In other words, don’t expect any kind of sequel shake-ups or further evolution across these 100 minutes. That might count as diminishing returns for some: a sequel as…

Score : 7.9/10 ✅

I missed this one last year, forgot about it when it was released on VOD this year, and then realized that I needed to watch it before the fourth one (which, like the previous two entries, was going to be available at Fantasia). And like a complete imbecile, forgot about it again (Urghhhh!!!). I couldn't procrastinate any longer. I had less than 12 hours to do the task. So, the plan was to wake myself up at about 6 AM. Watching it. Eat, shower, leave for work, work all day, go to Fantasia and watch the new chapter.

Mission accomplished.

To me, No Way Out was a slight letdown. All the ingredients were there to make…

This is the first entry in this series that had to work to win me over. Don't get me wrong: if you're just here to see Ma Dong-seok deliver devastating punches to a gallery of interchangeable criminal lowlifes, then you're going to go home happy. But the third movie in the series that started with 2017's "The Outlaws" finds Ma Dong-seok and the filmmakers starting to feel very comfortable in their role...I might suggest a little too​ comfortable.

This is easily their most commercial and crowd-pleasing installment yet, but it's also lost any element of danger or edge: considering how many characters are stabbed by knives, bludgeoned to death by crowbars, or sliced and diced by a Japanese katana, it's…
